title: Steven Gerrard says he would've 'loved' playing under Jurgen Klopp and admits he may have left early
text:
Steven Gerrard admits he would have 'loved' to have played under Jurgen Klopp at Liverpool and therefore states he perhaps left the club a year too early.

Gerrard departed at the end of the 2014-15 season, after 710 appearances and nine major honours to his name, opting to join MLS side LA Galaxy for a fresh challenge.

The home-grown former captain nearly won the Premier League in 2014, finishing second to Manchester City, but his final season ended in a sixth-place showing and an embarrassing 6-1 defeat at Stoke in his final game.

Steven Gerrard was the captain at Liverpool for 12 years before leaving the club in 2015

Gerrard shakes Klopp's hand ahead of the 2018 Champions League Final in Kiev, Ukraine

STEVEN GERRARD'S LIVERPOOL HONOURS Champions League: 2005 FA Cup: 2001, 2006 League Cup: 2001, 2003, 2012 UEFA Cup: 2001 UEFA Super Cup: 2001 Community Shield: 2006

But in October 2015, manager Brendan Rodgers was sacked and Jurgen Klopp replaced him, and Gerrard accepts he could've hung around a little longer to play under the charismatic German.

'I always had little thoughts as I've gone along,' Gerrard told Sky Sports.

'Should I have stayed at Liverpool? Should I have signed a year extension? Maybe I might have been able to have that cameo under Jurgen Klopp as maybe a squad player.

'These things always cross my mind but, look, I made decisions. I am very proud of my Liverpool career, I am very proud of where I am up to now in my management.

'I want to give that my full focus and keep trying to learn and grow and improve and see where that journey takes me now.'

After winning his first trophy as Liverpool manager with last year's Champions League triumph, Klopp is hunting an elusive Premier League crown, and the Reds are currently eight points clear at the top-of-the-table after maintaining a 100% start to their league campaign.

Klopp lifts the Champions League trophy following Liverpool's win against Tottenham in June

Gerrard is now the manager of Rangers, who are currently top of the Scottish Premiership

Although unlikely to still be involved as a player - he is now 39 - Gerrard concedes it has crossed his mind on a few occasions what would've happened if he stayed a little longer.

'Of course, you always have little moments,' Gerrard admitted.

'Imagine if I'd stayed at Liverpool a bit longer and maybe I'd bumped into Jurgen Klopp, as someone who could maybe have given me 10-15 minutes off the bench.

The 39-year-old donned the strips of Liverpool and Rangers in a legends match on Saturday

'Of course it has crossed my mind - I would have loved that.'

As it is, Gerrard departed and enjoyed a season-and-a-half in America before retiring, and taking up a coaching role with the Liverpool Under-18s.

He is now into his second season as Rangers manager, and he donned the kit of both his current and former club in a charity game between Rangers Legends and Liverpool Legends at Ibrox on Saturday.
